newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan subway guru ordered out of court again.
newsitem.headline: Japan subway guru ordered out of court again.

text.p: Japanese doomsday cult guru Shoko Asahara, charged with murder for a deadly gas attack on Tokyo subways, was thrown out of court on Thursday for interrupting his own trial.
In what has become a regular occurrence in his 10-month trial, Asahara ignored pleas by his lawyers to keep quiet, shouting at witnesses and judges presiding over the hearing.
"This is a court, so act like a judge. You have no right to stop me, the defendant, from speaking my point of view," Asahara said when the judges warned him to stop his outbursts.
However, Asahara, who is charged with masterminding the March 1995 sarin nerve gas attack on Tokyo's subway system which killed 12 people and made thousands ill, refused to back down.
"Why do Japanese people have to be reverent all the time?" Asahara said.
His outburst came during testimony by forensic experts on the deadly effects of the sarin nerve gas.
In what has become a regular feature of his twice-monthly appearances, Asahara swayed restlessly in his chair before launching into his tirades.
On Thursday, one of his targets was former disciple Yoshihiro Inoue, who was not in the courtroom at the time.
Inoue, who has given evidence against Asahara, is also on trial for his part in the attack.
"Why must others be arrested for complicity when Inoue was the one who planned everything?" Asahara said.
The remarks led the judges to order court officials to escort Asahara back to his cell.
Inoue, once Asahara's most loyal lieutenant, served as intelligence chief of the Aum Shinri Kyo (Supreme Truth Sect).
Inoue has testified that Asahara ordered the gassing to back up his mystic vision of an Armageddon that would leave the sect in power in Japan.
Asahara, who has refused to enter a plea, is being tried on murder charges for the subway deaths as well as other charges ranging from kidnapping to illegal production of drugs and weapons.
